'''Pembroke College''' is one of the [[University of Oxford]]'s 39 constituent colleges.

[[J.R.R. Tolkien]] became [[Rawlinson and Bosworth Professor of Anglo-Saxon]] in [[1925]]. Despite being a fellow at the college he chose not to live at the college. During this period he wrote ''[[The Hobbit]]'', ''[[The Fellowship of the Ring]]'' and ''[[The Two Towers]]'' as well as [[Beowulf: The Monsters and the Critics]]. He kept the position for twenty years before moving to Merton College in [[1945]] and taking up the position of Professor of English Language and Literature.<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://www.pmb.ox.ac.uk/sites/default/files/migrated/library/tolkien_booklet_archives.pdf|articlename=J.R.R. Tolkien in Oxford|dated=|website=pmb.ox.ac.uk|accessed=7 February 2024}}</ref> Tolkien seemed to have disliked Pembroke. In a [[letter]] ([[Letter 96]]) to his son, he described Pembroke as "miserable" and said he desired be in a "real college".<ref>{{L|96}}</ref>

Since 2013 Pembroke Colleges has delivered an annual lecture called The J.R.R. Tolkien Lecture on Fantasy.<ref>[https://tolkienlecture.org/about-us/ About Us], The J.R.R. Tolkien Lecture on Fantasy Literature</ref>

[[File:Tim Tolkien at Pembroke College (2024).webp|thumb|Tim Tolkien next to the statue he created for Pembroke College in [[2024]].]]
In [[2024]] a memorial to J.R.R. Tolkien was unveiled, created by [[Tim Tolkien]], the great-nephew of J.R.R. Tolkien.<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c255zgwze77o.amp|articlename=Tolkien memorial unveiled at author's college|dated=June 12th, 2024|website=https://www.bbc.com/|accessed=June 12th, 2024}}</ref>
